participants.participant: Denis Fiévet, Vice President, Financial Communication and Investor Relations
Denis Fiévet, Vice-President, Financial Communication and Investor Relations

plist.p: Good morning everybody and welcome to the Pernod Ricard auditorium welcome to you too who are following us online. Speaking of which, I will ask those of you in the auditorium to please turn-off your BlackBerries to improve the quality of sound for those listening in online.

So this morning Pierre Pringuet and Gilles Bogaert will take you through our consolidated accounts for the '09, '10 period running from the 1st of July 2009 to the 30th of June 2010. The presentation will last about an hour leaving you a good half hour for questions.

As we discuss right now, we alternate between questions from the floor and questions that we take from those of you listening in online. The procedure is now well known, you just introduce yourselves, say who you're representing and ask no more than three questions to ensure that as many people as possible get the opportunity to raise their questions.
So busy schedule this morning, so let me give the floor straightaway to Pierre Pringuet.
Thank you, Denis Fiévet, good morning everybody.

Strong healthy growth for the period that just ended. Just three figures to illustrate that: organic growth of sales 2%, profit from recurring operations up 4% and as I told you, advertising and promotion expenditure up 5%. Remember that that was the ambition; that is what we said we'd do, that is what we did and of course, free cash flow from recurring operations of 1,160 million.

Now, just a few landmark events, contrasted economic situation strong growth in most economies, particularly in Asia, very gradual recovery of consumer spending in the U.S. among others, but certainly, consumer spending has picked up as our own depletion figures demonstrate, as the various panels suggest also. Now the situation is highly contrasted in Europe, we're not going to talk about Greece, but there have been various austerity measures and the situation is nonetheless on the up.

During the financial period, the euro-dollar parity varied from 1.18 to 1.60 just to show you how much the currency has fluctuated, and of course Venezuelan Bolivar, well, we will come back to that later on. Very importantly for the Group, interest rates are a historically low level both in euro and U.S. dollar denominated borrowings.

We have also completed our disposals program with the sale of Tia Maria and some of our Scandinavian assets. And we have also issued a 1.2 billion bond in March of this year. So come at these figures now in greater detail. Key figures: sales minus 2% published but organic growth of 2%, and if you look at the top fourteen, you will see that the volume was up 2%, sales were up 4%. That means two things.

First of all, that our strategic brands are actually growing faster than the portfolio as a whole, largely due to our A&P expenditure, and on the other hand we've had a positive mix price effect such as organic growth of 4%, advertising and promotional expenditure. As we told you 2008-2009, we had to cut back on spending in the, because of the crisis, but we assured that we will be reinvesting this year. We have kept our promise. We are now back investing at the same level as before the crisis. If you look at the marketing spend as a percentage of sales, we are back at the same level as in 2007-2008. And of course profit from recurring operations €1.795 million, that's organic growth of 4%. This is despite the increased investment in A&P, but we'll go through this in some detail later on with Gilles Bogaert.

Our attributable net profit from recurring operations of €1,001 million, we exceeded that 1 billion mark for the first time in 2008-2009. Now if we factor out ForEx, or currency translation, if you prefer, we would have been up 7%. This year that is what we expect to happen in view of foreign exchange trends.

Now group share of net profit was up 1% to €951 million. Strong cash generation, I won't go back on to this again. And if we adjust or if we exclude conversion adjustments, remember the dollar was at a high on the 30th of June, but if we factor out conversion adjustments, our debt would have been down by over €1 billion, that's €1,090 million, which means that in terms of net debt ratio, net debt to EBITDA ratio we were down from 5.4, which was the ratio at the end of June 2009 to 4.9, which was the ratio as of June 30, 2009 (sic) [2010]. Remember debt reduction was our top priority for the year and will continue to be a priority for the current year.

So we're going to take a look at sales. First of all, focus on the fourth quarter, where we have achieved 7% growth. That was 3% organic growth, a 6% positive effect of currency translation and of course, corporate consolidation also had a positive effect, despite the disposal of Wild Turkey, Tia Maria and some of our Nordic assets.

As for the change in Q4 sales, well, this confirmed the positive trends we mentioned when we talked about our interim results, with strong growth in emerging markets, a recovery in certain markets such as Russia, South Korea, both are posting a positive growth again, and of course the Duty Free market, which is particularly important for premium brands. It's also, by the way, a good indicator of say, consumer sensitivity, if they're travelling and spending, it's a very, very positive sign.

We've also observed a gradual recovery in the U.S., depletion is back where it was in the past. Western Europe, finally, with still persistent difficulties in Spain, U.K. and Ireland, more recently in Greece, Greece was under a positive trend; well, that trend has come to an end with the austerity measures of this year.

Finally, again on Q4 sales, we had the negative impact; remember that shipments were anticipated in Q3. A number of festivities took place earlier this year than the past, there have also been a number of duty increases or excise duty increases in the countries mentioned as the U.K. China, Greece and Spain. Over the period as a whole, while the published sales figure was down 2%, internal growth of 2%, driven by the top 14, which were up 4% on average. Remember that in the second half of the year, our internal growth was all of 9%, positive organic growth.

Now the ForEx impact was much weaker over the year as a whole. In the first half year, the impact was over €180 million, that's a negative impact. So obviously in the second half year the situation was reversed, obviously due to the strengthening of the dollar. And I won't dwell on our disposals, which I've already mentioned twice.

Here you have a comparison quarter-on-quarter from the first quarter of 2008 right up to the fourth quarter of 2010. You see that the previous quarters really mirror one another. If you look at the half year that's on the right-hand side of this chart, H1 was up 5%, two years ago it was minus 3.

In the second half year we were down 7% in the first half two years ago, we were then up 9% giving us annual growth in '09-'10 of 2%. So the second half year was very clearly a period of strong recovery.

This chart is an analysis of our product portfolio. Remember that we classified – we defined our portfolio. We explained this in our Capital Market Day last May. Top 14 which is really the locomotive of growth is then followed by our 18 – Priority Premium Wines, Jacob's Creek among others, the 18 key local brands that did well, up 4% over the year.

The other products, which were down fractionally, but if anything that's good news because we have disposed of a certain number of businesses that weren't as profitable. So on whole you see that this is positive. So, there is a very positive growth mix effect and once again the locomotive of our growth has been the Top 14.

So, let's take a closer look at our portfolio. Beginning with the Top 14, that's 55% of the group sales by the way. Top 14 generates 55% of our sales. We'll give the percentages for the other categories as well.

On this chart you'll see that on the left hand column you have the organic growth, in the middle you have the organic growth of sales, volume on the left, sales in the middle. And on the right hand side you have the mix product effect. In green you have positive growth, blue is flat. That is the price or the mix price effect for our Top 14 brands. There is only one exception that is Royal Salute, which I'll comment in greater detail in a minute. But all the other brands in the Top 14, 13 out of 14 show at least a neutral, if not positive price mix effect. In other words we have created value with our Top 14 over the last year.

That's a performance that I'd like to draw your attention to in so far as it shows that what we said, we do. We said we would not accept any price compromise. Well that is now clearly in evidence on that chart.

So, let's take a look at these products beginning with Absolut Vodka, volume up 6%, sales up 6%. And we're talking about internal growth which factors out July. Remember Absolut was taken over on the 27th of July 2008. So for the purposes of comparison we did not include July.
So, strong performance by the brand with a price mix effect that was neutral overall, but we have reviewed our prices downwards in the U.S.

Our reference price is now just fractionally below $20. Remember that the increase was decided just before the prices implemented on the 1st of October 2008, bad timing, you're saying; quite right. So however, despite that decrease in the U.S., we've increased our Absolut price in all other markets. Overall the effect was neutral.

In the U.S., we have reinvested in the brand. We have taken a number of initiatives and a number of examples mentioned here. The Absolut Lemon Drop that you see which is one of a number of cocktail drinks, magnificent advertisement deal with a wonderful video spot that we'd be delighted to show you, if you like, so we've reinvested in the brand and of course, this is in evidence in the figures.

Negative depletions in the first half year, in fact, down 5%, positive depletion in the second half year, up 2%, if you look at the Nielsen panel figures well they were positive. The NABCA was negative, but more recently the figures have improved. Very strong growth in a number of export markets with double-digit growth from France, Mexico, Canada, Brazil, Greece, without forgetting Africa, Middle East, Oceania and Asia. So, Absolut is a brand that is really in line with our expectations when we made the acquisition, really rolling it out worldwide.

We've repositioned our prices in the U.K. and Germany with lower off-trade volumes, but a very, very small downturn sales and much better presence in the on trade part of the business, I hope they have it in your favor bar because we're always furious when we find that Absolut isn't being sold in bars so we're remedying that.
We've taken numerous marketing initiatives I've already mentioned one or two, but I would like to draw your attention to a very original initiative this is the Spike Jonze's video called "I'm Here".

This is a video that was broadcast online. You have to subscribe to attend so you have to take a proactive approach. But 600,000 people watched it. This is a 30 minute film. So it's not a quick video clip. 600,000 people watched it. 1.2 million visitors to the dedicated website another figure I saw is that we've had tens of thousands of mentions in the press and the various media. So an excellent and very successful initiative among many others.

This brings me to Chivas; volumes up 1%, sales were up 5%, the mix/price effect was positive, and strong upturn in growth, Chivas 18 up 41% – that's on 18 year old Chivas. The situation improved in Europe particularly in the second half year in Russia and even in Spain the situation improved in Spain in the second half year, we saw a very good performance in France too.

Signs of improvement in the U.S. We've been reinvesting with Chivas, the focus is on the 18 year old version. So despite the negative trend in the past, we've succeeded in turning depletions around. They were up 1% in the second half year. Nielsen panel figures were negative for the year as a whole, yet more recent figures are much more positive, but double-digit growth in Latin America which is a very important whiskey market.

In Asia the situation has improved somewhat. Remember that we had a – nothing the first half year because we took over from the previous distributor in Japan. Difficulties in Thailand, but doubt-digit growth again in China. So very good results for Chivas in Asia.

Strong recovery of the Duty Free market in the second half of the year, with success of the Live with Chivalry campaign, its being going very, very well and I'd also like to draw your attention to the last campaign called Age Matters.

We discussed this advertisement with the Scotch Whiskey Association which supported the initiative. This is all about reminding consumers when you put 18 or 25 years old on a bottle of whiskey, this is a sign of quality and that's very important. Consumers, by the way, are convinced of that. They know that Aged whiskies are very, very good. I think the press mentioned this some 80,000 times – 80 – 80,000 times.

Ballantine's, situation a bit more difficult because of the Spanish market. Ballantine's Finest in particular suffered. While figures were down in Spain, Germany likewise fared poorly as did Central Europe. However, the sales grew in France and grew strongly in Poland, Portugal and Latin America. And we are very happy with the performance of Ballantine's with the exception of the Spanish market which we hope to see tail off very soon.
The higher qualities fell 7%, but picked up very sharply in the second half year up 15% largely driven by the Asian Duty Free markets. Again this is a good indicator of consumer confidence.
We also repackaged the 12-year old versions – 12-year old and older versions, extended our Plan B campaign, and were very, very successful with our Ballantine's Open golf tournament in Korea.

Martell very good growth again, volumes up 6%, sales up 12%, VS was still down. Cordon Bleu (sic) [Noblige] up 34%, Cordon Bleu up 13%, remarkable growth in most Asian countries, the mix has improved.

We were at the Shanghai World Fair and we chose not to inhabit the French pavilion, but we were on the expo boulevard which is at the entrance to the Shanghai World Fair. This is the main boulevard leading up to the entrance.
Martell sponsored the art of good living in China, which I think is a very good positioning. This is by the way the seventh Shanghai World Fair that we have attended with Martell.

This brings me to Jameson. Double-digit growth again, volumes up 9%, sales up 12%. In the U.S. depletions were up 24%, confirmed by the Nielsen figure up 16%, NABCA up 22%. Great success of the Lost Barrel video which was awarded a prize in the U.S that was last May. With the exception of Ireland, Jameson did well in the U.K., in Eastern Europe in the second half the year, in France, in Scandinavia. We accelerated our growth in South Africa, particularly in the second half. So this is a brand that is as successful as ever.

Havana Club, volumes up 3%, sales up 5%. We grew very strongly in the second half year; volumes up 13% despite persistent difficulties in our two historical markets, namely Spain and Italy. But Havana Club grew in numerous markets, particularly in Germany which has become Havana Club's biggest market in terms of volumes, obviously, driven by the 3-year old version. We were convinced that we could achieve a million cases in Germany, we have and of course with the new communications or advertising platform called "Nothing compares to Havana," a very, very interesting and flexible campaign.

Now, Royal Salute is the exception to that, as I told you, despite the fact that Glenlivet was up 6%, sales up 1%. This is because of the sales channel mix combination with very strong growth in the duty free market, but duty free prices are slightly lower than in domestic markets. However, there is no A&P expenditure. Duty free is a very profitable channel because there is no A&P investment, but prices are lower. Now because the duty free market picked up quicker than domestic markets, we have achieved this effect. Remember Royal Salute is one of our top 14, but this is mainly sold in Asia.

We've taken numerous initiatives, particularly in advertising with the launch of the "62 Gun Salute – The Pinnacle of Scotch Whisky," which was positioned at $2200 in duty free. Not many whiskies in that price range. Same type of price as Lord and Martell, this is a – these are ultra-premium products. And we believe that this will be very, very helpful for the brand and it's not the only initiative we'll be taking in this area. The Glenlivet saw its volumes up 5%, sales up 7%. Volumes increased in the U.S. with depletions up 4%. All the indicators are in the green. Very strong growth in Asia, particularly in Taiwan and duty free markets in Europe down fractionally, but almost entirely because of the U.K.

Now, we have great confidence in the future of this brand because we have doubled our distilling capacity and His Royal Highness Prince Charles came to the inauguration on the 4th of June 2010, which is clear evidence of the importance of this brand in the Scottish heritage.

Beefeaters, volumes stable, sales up 1%. Good performance in France – sorry this is Ricard, we confused logos and figures there. This is Ricard to begin with, sorry. Forget about Beefeater for a second.

Ricard, volume stable and growth – sales up 1%. In France, we achieved a growth, 1% growth, our volumes increased 3% in the off-trade market, despite the fact that the market was down 0.3%. But, on-trade was down. I think three or four bars or cafés closing down every day in France, which is a trend that is not showing any signs of being reversed. So anyway a lot of initiatives were taken. We began with a 35 centiliter bottle for the very first time, the idea being that you can have it on the table, if you have a certain number of friends in a bar, you can order a half bottle that's a 37 – 35 centiliter bottle, much more moderate.

Beefeater this time, yes this time it is indeed Beefeater I'm talking about, volumes down 1%, sales up 1%. Beefeater was very resilient in Spain. We outperformed the market, and we were down 2%, but the market was down 3%. U.S. is still a difficult market for Beefeater, we developed Beefeater 24, we're talking about 12,000 cases, but growth was very, very strong.

Remember selective on trade distribution, we do not sell Beefeater in the off-trade, but even in the on-trade it's only in up market bars. We're really trying to reestablish Beefeater's brand as a premium brand.

It's actually twice the price of standard Beefeater, and of course, we have an advertising campaign called "Forever London," with a digital version as well. I think we're doing what it takes to support this brand.

Malibu volume down 1%, sales down 1%, and that's something of a disappointment. We began our new advertising platform in the U.S. "Radio Boom Boom," as it's called. We started to roll-out the campaign in the U.S. This is mainly an online – digital online campaign, which went well in the U.S. Depletions were up 4%, Nielsen and NABCA figures were stable or good, but the trend was then reversed in the second half of the year.

There was a lag then in rolling out the campaign elsewhere and of course we can't apply it in France, so we can't roll it out in France for obvious reasons. We also took a number of marketing initiatives the Malibu cocktails, which were launched in large volumes, these are starter bottles, 75 centiliter bottles or in some cases, in 1.5 or 1.7 liter plastic containers. Now that went very, very well.

This is really for outdoor consumption, barbecues, for instance, beach parties, just add ice cubes and that's it. Another campaign that went very well is one called, "Malibu By U bottle." You decorate the bottle yourself. You can see examples of our consumers' creativity on the screen here and this is all done online. As you can see we're doing a lot of digital advertising.

Kahlúa, volume down 1% sales down 1%. While we knew this was a difficult brand, the initiatives we took in the past didn't go well. In particular, the campaign with the Aztec Gods. We have continued with Kahlúa and Kahlúa – kept them within the Absolut company because there are lot of similarities between these brands in terms of type of consumers and type of consumption. So we'll see in six-months' time, we'll take stock of the situation then.

Champagnes, Champagne was difficult all year but certainly the second half was better. 2010 saw Champagne recover, I hope that recovery will be confirmed, which we'll see over the full year, the volume was down 9%, in the second half it was up 1%, Perrier-Jouët down 2% over the year, but up 20% in the second half year. So you'll see that the situation has improved drastically in the second half year, we hope that will continue.

We're pleased with our performance particularly with Mumm in France, but also in Japan with Perrier-Jouët, in the U.S. as well. In the second half year, we've had positive depletions. We hope that the spring will confirm this trend.

Jacob's Creek volume down 6%, sales down 2% and these two, Jacob's Creek and Brancott between them account for 5% of the Group's sales. This is half of the still wines business which does not include champagnes, of course, just to give you some idea of what proportion of our sales they account for. There you can see very quickly Jacob's Creek.

Jacob's Creek volume is down 10%, sales are down 5% and the contribution is flat. So as far as Jacob's Creek is concerned, we are still divesting from the U.K. market. Mass retail wishes to sell three bottles for 15 or even 10 sterling. But as you all know, duties are very high in the U.K. and it's not a profitable business. So we've decided to step away.

So there is a strong decline in the U.K. as far as we are concerned. But conversely, we made inroads on most other markets that are far more profitable: Australia, the U.S., Sweden and China are cases in point and we have this new True Character platform, which has been successful.
Moving on to Brancott now, so this is the brand that was formerly called Montana. It was called Brancott in the U.S. because Montana is a state, of course, the capital of which is Helena.

And, of course, it was somewhat confusing. We ran a survey and we reached the conclusion that Brancott Estate, which is the origin of the brand where it's produced is the name with the greatest clout. So we brought the brand together under the Brancott Estate banner. And that will be complete by the end of the year. So as you can see, apart from the U.K., the performance of the brand has been very good. Last but not least, we are the official sponsor of the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand which will further the clout of the brand worldwide.
Campo Viejo is our Rioja brand, volumes up two, sales are up one decline in the U.K. due to our high value strategy but strong growth elsewhere.

And finally our Graffigna brand are the wines in Argentina post very good performance. You see that the brand has been declining on its domestic market, Argentina, but it has been growing, very sharply so, elsewhere.

These are our 18 key local spirits brands. You see that volume and sales increased handsomely with no price mix effect and these brands account for 17% of group sales. So 55% for the Top 14, the top four wines brands account for 5, and here you have 17% of group sales. And you have a detailed explanation.

And I need to move on. In particular, Imperial is growing once again in South Korea. Imperial is a Scotch whisky available in 12 and 17 year old versions. We were expecting the rebound of South Korea and that has been confirmed and there is continuing strong growth of local whisky brands in India, Royal Stag, Blender's Pride. We have a few difficulties with Ararat in Russia, and with Wyborowa in Poland and with 100 Pipers in Thailand.
So that gives you an overview of the brands and Gilles Bogaert is now going to tell you all about the numbers.
Thank you, Pierre.

Good morning, everyone. I would like to walk you through our income statement. As Pierre said, we have 4% growth in our profit from recurring operations, which is quite sound because we do have a 2% top line growth, whereas top line was flat last year. But we also have a sharp rise in our gross margin after logistics costs from 58.4 to 59.6%. In other words, we have a favorable price mix effect. In other words, we made no compromise on prices. And finally, we bolstered the investments in our brands with 5% growth. Last year, there was a 7% drop, if you recall. So quite clearly, this profitability is not encroaching upon future potential.

Now let's take a look at the various effects. There was a negative, minus 3% group effect, €63 million, primarily due to the disposals; Wild Turkey and Tia Maria. There was a negative foreign exchange impact €58 million, which is solely ascribed to Venezuela because the other ForEx impact – there were plusses and minuses and it was a wash in fact. And things improved over the year, in Venezuela the bolivar was devaluated in early January 2010 from 2.15 to 4.30 that's how the rate changed, quite a swing and at the same time there were increasing difficulties to access foreign currency. So what we did to consolidate the accounts of our subsidiary is that we used the parity that we noted for currency transfers in Venezuela. In other words, 6.40 between the dollar and the bolivar. So between 2.15, the official rate last year, all you have to do is divide the bolivar by three from the previous year.

As I was saying there was a sharp rise in gross margin. Organic growth is 4%. It is twice as strong as the sales growth. There are three factors that account for this very good performance. First of all, price mix effect, it's very good. The top 14 brands increased or grew twice as fast as group sales.

We defended our prices. We even hiked our prices for a great many brands and a great many markets. So 1.8% price increase overall for the top 14 brands over the year. And we continued to tame our cost of goods sold and we kept that flat for the year.

Regarding advertising and promotion, as previously announced, we significantly stepped up our investments with a 5% jump, with a 22% leap in the second half, which helps us achieve a 17.8% ratio of A&P over sales. It was 17.2 last year, as Pierre pointed out; we are back to the pre-crisis A&P over sales ratio.

Three-quarters of our investments are ascribed to our strategic brands, the Top 14. The investment ratio for the Top 14 is around 24%. And there was a qualitative improvement of the mix of advertising and promotional expenditures, because the media spent, which is of course a long-term investment increased faster than our marketing spent because we have an 11% increase in media spend for the fiscal year.

As a consequence of all of this, the contribution after A&P jumped 4% and the ratio also improved in spite of the fact that we continue to increase our investments in our brands. Regarding structured costs, if you exclude other income and expenses we – it was 1% – a mere 1% rise in the structured costs.

First of all, we tamed our costs quite tightly. We reorganized our subsidiaries in a great many difficult markets: Ireland, the U.K., Spain are cases in point. Also, we had frozen the salaries of all Executive Committees at the beginning of the year. And we did not run any stock option plan in June 2009.

And – there was defense, but there was also offense. We decided to beef-up our operations where we have the highest growth potential, notably in emerging markets such as China, India, African markets in Africa; now, there is emerging potential there and Japan, following the takeover of the distribution of Chivas, notably.

Now all this leads us to a 4% growth in profit from recurring operations, PRO, which is greater than the objective that we guided you to at the beginning of the year, which was between 1 and 3%. And the PRO organic growth rate is identical to last year's. But this time it includes a significant increase in A&P spend, that 5% I was telling you about.

Let's take a look at the performance on a regional basis now. As last year, Asia, rest of the world remained the key driver of organic growth; 66 million in blue here, the 14% organic growth. Conversely, Europe was the most – was the region that was most adversely hit by the crisis. This is especially true for Spain and the U.K.

So let's start off with the leading region for Pernod Ricard. Asia and rest of the world, this is definitely the growth driver. And the Group is a leader on these key markets and we are even stronger now that the year has elapsed. You see a 9% increase in sales, and a 14% increase in PRO.

China is one of the key countries obviously, double-digit growth there. And there was a very favorable mix quality effect for Martell, and this was the case in previous years. As Pierre mentioned we had a negative technical impact in the fourth quarter given that there were price increases in April, but the underlying trend remains excellent. Wholesaler sales and consumer demand are very buoyant starting in Q4.

India is still growing strong, mainly on the strength of its local whiskey brands: Royal Stag, Blenders Pride and Imperial Blue. South Korea posted very good news this year, because the trend reversed. The market suffered considerably in the first year of the crisis. But business has recovered. And this is also the case for Duty Free markets which are, of course, of consequential size in Asia.

Africa, Middle East still a small region, but it's highly profitable and growth there is double-digit, so quite clearly Africa and the Middle East are definitely growth areas as far emerging markets were concerned. Conversely, Thailand declined because of political turmoil. A word about the ratios here, gross margin and marketing expense ratios in Asia/Rest of World are highly impacted by the sales growth or slightly affected by sales growth in India.

Americas 4% organic sales growth, 1% organic profit from recurring operations growth, Latin America drove that growth. We considerably stepped up our investments in the Americas, as you see 7% above Group average increase there. It is of strategic importance for the Group. This is true for the U.S. and the two South American tigers, if I may say so, Mexico and Brazil.

In the U.S., the business was flat. If you take a look at organic sales growth, shipments and depletions, everything was pretty much flat, but there was an improved trend because depletions in H2 posted plus one, whereas overall, they were at minus two in H1. Absolut followed the trend owing to price hikes or price changes we were at plus 2% in H2, whereas we were at minus five in H1. Malibu and Glenlivet performed well. The great success of Jameson carried through with growth in excess of 20% and Kahlúa and Seagram's Gin slipped.

Central and South America, satisfactory growth, especially ascribable to the iconic Chivas and Absolut brands and not to mention the Something Special Scotch Whisky. There was a negative ForEx impact in the Americas somewhat ascribed to the U.S. dollar, but essentially due to the negative impact of Venezuela that I have already elaborated on.

Europe: in France, minus 5% sales growth, minus 3% PRO growth. In Western Europe excluding France there were some difficulties. Spain, the U.K. were difficult, but there are countries that moved up. Germany, which is a major player in the region, and smaller countries such as Sweden and Belgium that fared quite well.

And Duty Free picked up in the second half. In Eastern Europe, there was good recovery in H2, especially in Russia. Russia closed the year with slight topline growth. Ukraine did well too. The situation was more difficult in Poland, essentially because of our local vodka brands that slipped. The face value decline in the region's PRO was primarily due to the negative scope and ForEx impacts.

France now overall, France once again posted good performance 7% PRO growth. Flat sales, of course, there are pluses and minuses, Absolut and Havana Club grew sharply. Ricard and the whiskies performed well. By the whiskies, I mean Chivas, Ballantine, Jameson and Clan Campbell, but Champagnes, notably Mumm and Pastis 51 were not sparkling performers. But given the increase in the share of high gross margin brands and contained structure costs in France, we were able to get a sharp rise in our PRO sales ratio, 24.2 to 25.9%, and a 7% rise in profit from recurring operations overall.

All this gives you pie chart analysis of all this. By geographic regions, sales on left, PRO on the right, Asia – RoW has become the group's main region for Pernod Ricard, plus 32% given its excellent organic growth. The Americas suffered from negative ForEx impact. And you see that the contribution of each region is increasingly consistent between sales and profit from recurring operations.

The new economies, as last year, proved instrumental in the Group's growth an 8% increase in organic growth. They account for one-third of sales, one-third of PRO, just as profitable was mature markets and given the strong positions that we enjoy in these new economies and given the growth potential that remains untapped. This is of course critical for our future growth, key strength for future group growth.

Still walking down the income statement, now we're moving on to financial income from recurring operations. There was sharp improvement over the year here with a sharp decline in net interest. Of course there was deleveraging and the drop in the average cost of debt from 4.8 to 4.3% this year.

The other income and expense items, well, overall there is a rise there. Amortization of bank charges paid in relation to the implementation of the V&S syndicated loan. We're looking at €11 million there and there was an increase in other income and expense items primarily due to pension commitments.

For next year, based on current interest rates, our target for '10-'11 is to maintain the average cost of borrowing below 5%. 2009, 2010 was a decisive step in group deleveraging. It shows up in net debt excluding translation differences, the debt dropped €1.090 million. And there was a strong free cash flow generation to the tune of €1.110 billion.

Towards the – at the end of June, we were pretty close to the strongest point that the dollar ever hit, $1.23 to the euro, whereas it was 1.41 at the beginning of the fiscal year and at the average it was 1.31.

So here you have the details of free cash flow from recurring operations, after recurring operations €1,160 million is pretty flat from last year on a like-for-like basis, in spite of factoring, which is less favorable than last year. Last year, we set up the factoring program generating €350 million in cash. The impact this year is a mere €84 million, but still favorable. This good performance in terms of cash flow generation stems from our controlled working capital requirement, which remained pretty much a wash, our strict control over growth of ageing inventories, cognac, whiskies.

This is very much in line with what we had anticipated. We made efforts to substantially reduce our wine inventory in the Pacific region. It was €40 million decline there, a great many initiatives unleashed, made that performance possible and for other factors there was a €76 million decline essentially due to the disposals of receivables.

CapEx was down from last year €184 million, quite well curved and borrowing costs declined, which was favorable on the cash aspect of interest. Also you see that non-recurring related free cash flow posts a favorable trend. First of all, there was a decrease in cash outflows relating to the integration of Vin & Sprit and we also cashed in a 105 million tax refund in the U.S. for carry-back. Now deleveraging also bears out in the net debt over EBITDA ratio, as you know there are two ways of determining this, you take your net debt at closing rate and you take your net debt at average rate. Usually when there is not too much currency volatility, there is not much of a difference. But this year given the swing from 1.41 to 1.23, there is quite a disparity between the two approaches here.

The average rate approach is of course a most salient one and that is the one we use for our covenants, our syndicated loans in late June. We're not allowed to go above 75 (sic) [6.75] and now we are at 4.9. As – I need to say that the ratio dropped from 5.4 to 4.9 over the year essentially due to organic EBITDA growth and very strong cash flow generation over the fiscal year. Moving on to debt maturity, as you can see 2013 and 14 are the big years. Of course there is something to pay back in the next few years, but given the cash we have and given the €2.2 billon, we have in undrawn lines and given the cash flow we're going to generate in the coming months and years, it's fair to confidently assert that we can cover our requirements up until 2012-2013 included. Bond debt represented a little over one-third of our gross debt and as you know our determination is to continue to balance out our financing between banking and bond debt by 2013.

Now let's take a look at what this looks like with a currency breakdown, 60% in dollars. The dollar portion increased somewhat especially due to the fact that the dollar strengthened against the euro. The debt breakdown by currency is consistent with that of EBITDA. Well, that's how we structured it. And according to rates – the nature of the rates, well our policy is to have one-third of our debt maintained at a variable rate. We were at 32% in late June, so very much on the money as far as that is concerned.

Income tax. On recurring operations first. We have a 20.9% effective income tax, which is in line with our anticipation and with our guidance at the beginning of the year. It's up from last year. It was at 16.6% last year, and it did benefit from the effects of the V&S acquisition.

Non-recurring items, well there is a positive €48 million impact there. There are various factors there. Savings related to non-recurring expense and the favorable impact of the foreign exchange movements, which generated deductible foreign exchange losses.
Minor interests and other items, from minus 21 to minus 27, essentially due to the good performance by Havana Club in Canada and in South Korea, where we have minority stakes.

So, all told, we have 1 billion in group share of net profit from non-recurring operations down 1%. So, virtually stable in spite of unfavorable foreign exchange effects and higher income tax, reflecting sales resilience and controlling cost. At a constant ForEx, 7% growth in Group share of net profit from recurring operations.

Net earnings per share from recurring operations. This brings us to non-recurring items. We have capital gains and losses on disposal and asset valuation. A couple of negative impacts due to disposals. A total of minus €60 million. Also the 116 million negative impact on impairment tests, particularly on Kahlua for €100 million.

Other non-recurring income and expenses are actually an income of €88 million, particularly due to the variations to risk for – risks and contingencies. The other operating income expenses was a negative 88 million. Non-recurring financial items totaled €10 million, mainly currency translation losses.
